Hey, I'll be on @CNN in a few minutes talking with the wonderful @AnaCabrera about the jobs report, inflation, gas prices and all things economics. Lemme surprise you by making the point that some of the news is good news. https://t.co/8ebZYQkcVY

It's clear that the economy is slowing a bit. And there's a lot of uncertainty about our economic future. And that uncertainty means a recession is *possible* (but so is an ongoing BOOM).

"Forecasting" the present moment is easier, and the data are clear: We're not in recession.
Point is, for all of our pre-pandemic history, the idea that jobs growth as rapid as it currently is would be coupled with "recession!" talk would have been thought laughable.

Over the past three months (a time of peak "recession" talk!), jobs growth has averaged +372k. For some context, realize that the economy *never* registered 3 months of employment growth this fast in the pre-pandemic 2000s.

Folks seem to have forgotten how rapid these rates are. https://t.co/OqgtAGfP1e
To put today's job growth context, it's worth noting that over the prior 20 years, payrolls growth has averaged only +92k. This is a much stronger than average rate of employment growth!
A reminder that there are still millions of people on the sidelines of the labor market.  https://t.co/6Jh15MGbaA

@joshtpm @byHeatherLong @swin24 Looks that way to my non-expert eyes, too:
https://t.co/fdHcfO266o

I'm not a big fan of reporting on the second derivative. A sophisticated reader might get what's going on, but others might miss the reality that:
- Employment is high (above pre-pandemic levels)
- Employment is growing rapidly (far faster than is typical)
https://t.co/d4V8CtrCcN

Point is, these data don't point to any inflationary pressures coming from the labor market. That doesn't resolve the question of how much is demand versus supply, as demand pressures can play out directly in the product market. But workers aren't the problem.

If you really want to know where the Fed's eyes will be in this report, it's all about hourly earnings.

And lemme tell you about an interesting trend:
- Over 2022 Q3, nominal wages grew at an annualized rate of +4.4%
- 2022 Q2: +4.6%
- 2022 Q1: +4.8%
- 2021 Q4: +6.1%
@joshtpm @byHeatherLong @swin24 Over the past three months, the labor force has risen +666k. Interpret that as you will.

The past three months of jobs gains are +537k in July, +315k in August and +253k in September.

By one view, data are noisy, so average those for an unsustainably fast +368k average rate.

By another, that's a trend with job growth slowing from unsustainable to sustainable.

The household survey tells a roughly similar story: Employment rose by +204k, but the dip in unemployment was somewhat aided by a slight (-57k) decline in the labor force. Over a longer time horizon labor force growth has been healthy so it's good to see those gains locked in.
(That's not a promise that the next few months will follow that soft landing script. It might; it might not. But right now, Jay Powell and his colleagues have to be feeling pretty happy.)

If you wanted to write the September script for what a perfect soft landing looked like, you might have drawn up these latest set of jobs numbers with employment growth continuing, but slowing to more sustainable rates, and wage growth running at rates unlikely to spark inflation

Nominal wages grew by +0.3% in September, an annual rate of only 3.8%. Over the past three months, the annualized rate is 4.4%, down from 4.6% over the previous three months.

When you look at recent data, there's no sense of a wage-price spiral in these numbers.

BLS is very clear that these numbers were unaffected by Hurricane Ian, which may well distort the jobs numbers over the next few months (as businesses both close, and then re-open and rebuild). https://t.co/GMAPqCqIaw

Payrolls rose a robust +263k in September, a touch above expectations.

Unemployment down a tick to 3.5%, equal to the lowest level in fifty years. Revisions also positive.

This is an economy that's still growing nicely. All that recession talk was empty.

The lesson: Making poverty reduction an explicit goal of policy works. The bigger question is the direction of anti-poverty policy as we emerge from the pandemic and emergency measures are dropped.

Summary

The bad: Inequality is still rising and is at a post-war high.
The good: Poverty remains near its historic lows (but still higher than other countries)
The very good: The gender wage gap is likely at an all-time low.
The amazing: Child poverty may be at an all-time low.

My students are often blown away by these numbers, learning that they're higher in the distribution than they had ever guessed.
I suspect this reflects the lack of mixing in the US, and the role of popular media.

(How many TV shows truly depict those below the 80th percentile?)

The simple facts about the distribution of income remain widely misunderstood.

HOUSEHOLD income distribution in 2021
10th percentile: $15,600
20th: $28,000
30th: $40,500
40th: $55,000
Median: $70,800
60th: $89,700
70th: $113,200
80th: $149,100
90th: $211,956

The gender wage gap is now the lowest on record.

Among full-time year-round workers the typical (median) woman earned $0.84 for every dollar earned by the median man.

[Before the "yeah buts" arrive, this summarizes the typical gap, and isn't intended to measure discrimination.] https://t.co/QWmpAe2i9J
Still, income remains stunningly unequally distributed: The poorest fifth of all households received 2.9% of all money income in 2021, while the richest fifth received 52.7%.

But realize that while inequality in money income rose, a lot of what we do to address inequality occurs through the tax system. Focusing instead on post-tax income suggests that inequality didn't rise quite so sharply. https://t.co/qV8MAPq2Ul

Income inequality rose fairly sharply last year, and while these data only go back to 1967, given what we know from other sources, it's likely that inequality is at a post-war high (though not an all-time high). https://t.co/psCjcVRjnV

The headline: Median household income, adjusted for inflation, fell a tick in 2021, but not by an amount that's statistically significant.

Note that this is adjusted using headline CPI, which rose 4.7% (average for 2021, compared with 2020 average). So in nominal terms it rose. https://t.co/JDHX4DI7sJ

I just tweeted about the latest poverty data (https://t.co/pi0IHQPDce). But there's also another big new Census data release today, on the distribution of income. (It comes from the same raw data.) 

Here's the data: https://t.co/X5DXdHEiVe

Lemme dig into it.
And if you want to know how to reduce poverty: Policy works. When people don't have enough money, giving them more money makes a difference! https://t.co/NQ47m6GZWg
Poverty rates are declining most dramatically for those minority groups which have historically  been most at risk. https://t.co/aAVzZnSK95

The biggest shift is a decline in child poverty. Just a stunning change. Child poverty is less than a third of what it was a decade ago. What a massive change in the prospects for our kids. https://t.co/cIJweCsl78
Don't let the headlines confuse you: Poverty is falling. Our attempts at helping low-income families are working.

You might wonder why "official" poverty remained high even as we did so much during the pandemic to support families. Those policy measures are better reflected in an alternative poverty measure which most experts prefer (the SPM). This measure shows poverty dropping dramatically https://t.co/jliFmoFuTC

Too many people have trouble keeping the following two facts in mind at the same time:
1. Racial and ethnic minorities are more likely to be in poverty than whites (that's why their blue bars are bigger than their orange bars)
2. But most people in poverty are non-Hispanic whites https://t.co/03Y1ONZID3
Poverty rates vary tremendously by demographics, and are much higher for high school dropouts (stay in school!), the unemployed, and single parent households. https://t.co/LjcUHIigLW

The headline official poverty rate of 11.6% is up a tick from last year (though this isn't a statistically significant rise). In broader perspective, poverty remains near historic lows. https://t.co/ClAR5DnRSw

Official poverty numbers for 2021 were just released. There's a ton of useful data here, so strap in. https://t.co/qR2QQ5fuwi
[These are data from the CPS ASEC ,and are the most commonly cited measures. The ACS yields a separate measure.]

If you're sick of reading my tweets about this morning's inflation report and would rather hear about it in a broad Aussie accent, then tune in to this Twitter spaces discussion in a few. @WendyEdelberg, @davidmwessel and I will chat about the numbers.
https://t.co/fLBZs04RPx

I expect that over the next year or so inflation will come down to rates of two or three-point-something. It'll become less of a concern for the general public (it's hard to tell the difference between 2% and 3% inflation), but this will remain a central concern for the Fed.

Putting the pieces together:The case for optimism on inflation is much weaker today. The case for pessimism -- wage-price spirals! unanchored expectations! -- also remains weak.

Headline inflation will come down, but it's hard to see a quick path to 2% inflation.

The case for pessimism is simpler: Inflation is uncomfortably high, and it doesn't appear to be coming down. The economy remains close to capacity, which will add inflationary pressure, even as some one-off factors (gas prices) dissipate.

Okay, I do have a pretty graph for this: Here's the NY Fed's Global Supply Chain Pressure Index (check it out!), which is clearly starting to look less unhealthy.
https://t.co/mdJHS4no4e https://t.co/gsyCtE58Yx

Cause for optimism #4: Global supply chains are slowly starting to unfurl. I don't have a pretty graph for this, but can tell you that the dishwasher I ordered a year ago finally arrived. That's data, right?
Cause for optimism #3: There's little evidence that nominal wage growth is taking off in the way that points to a wage-price spiral. https://t.co/NcQ9c4hC6W

Cause for optimism #2: Consumers' inflation expectations have fallen in recent weeks (likely guided down by lower gas prices). This helps make the case that inflation expectations remain anchored (for now). https://t.co/HpTkWhNOdG

There are three forward-looking indicators that might make a case for inflation optimism:
Cause for optimism #1. We know that gas prices have continued to fall even since the August CPI report. https://t.co/yrJhJBOQ2o

Looking forward, there are two especially salient price indices: Prices at the pump are falling rapidly, which will make consumers happy. But groceries ("Food at home" in BLS-speak) are also super salient, and they've risen 11.4% over the past year.

For sure you can lock in the Fed hiking rates by three-quarters of a percentage point. And realize that at least part of this is that to achieve its desired real rate, the nominal rate has to be higher when inflation is higher.

This seems the right framing: Core inflation has remained relatively constant as it has shifted from goods into services. But this is not benign. Team transitory was largely based on the view that a shock to goods prices would dissipate rather than spread.
https://t.co/KTh6OdtYIY

Equally, there's no evidence that inflation is taking off. Over the past three months, the core CPI rose by 1.6%, which is similar to the 1.5% rise over the previous three months.

What's disappointing here isn't that inflation is taking off, but rather that it hasn't reversed.

For some perspective: Basically last month's optimism has been countered by this month's pessimism. To state the obvious: Inflation remains an important and central concern and will be the focus of macro policy for some time to come.

This is a much much worse CPI report than anyone was expecting. The decrease in headline inflation due to lower energy prices is there, but the underlying rate -- best proxied by core inflation -- is running a fair bit higher than anyone forecast and most of us hoped.

Inflation for August is out, and average prices paid by consumers rose by only +0.1% compared with last month. Headline CPI remains an elevated 8.3% over the year.

Core inflation is the real gut punch, rising +0.6% in August, and it's now up +6.3% over the year.

In case you've ever wondered what Jobs Day looked like in my household, @BetseyStevenson is giving live responses on TV, I'm tweeting up a storm, my daughter is sleeping in, and my son realizing he has no parental attention is calling his best mate and sneaking in some Minecraft.

This jobs report puts less pressure on the Fed: Rising labor force participation suggests the economy has more capacity to grow, job growth is slowing to more sustainable rates, and moderate wage growth numbers are yet another data point failing to show a wage-price spiral.
The changing shape of our post-pandemic economy: https://t.co/5ir3V9SYyT

More on the non-acceleration of wage growth:
Over the past 3 months, wages have grown at an annualized rate of 4.8%, compared with 4.9% in the prior 3 months, 4.8% in the 3 months before that, and 6.3% in the 3 months before that.

My conclusion: Wage growth is a tad below 5%.
@blk_hd @BetseyStevenson She's downstairs on TV; I'm upstairs on my computer ;-)

But for the Fed / inflation watchers: There's simply no evidence of growing nominal wage pressure.

Wages have grown +4.9% over the past six months, down a bit from +5.5% over the prior six months.
Most important detail in this report may be what's happening to (nominal) wages, which grew +0.3%, a tick below expectations. Over the past year, wages have grown by +5.2%

It's kind of stunning how much oxygen was wasted through the first half of the year talking about a recession that clearly never happened.

(And lemme remind you, that I told you this in real time!)

That said, similar logic suggests that last month's payrolls growth was understated by around 100k.

Safest thing to do is focus on the three month average of job growth, which is running at a *very* healthy +378k

The headline payrolls growth may actually be somewhat overstated: Goldman has a nice analysis showing that the seasonal factors are distorted by the timing of the 2020 reopening, and so may overstate strength by around 100-150k. https://t.co/HBYevaRfKu

Don't be alarmed by the rise in unemployment: It's actually masking good news. In the household survey employment rose +442k, but the labor force grew even more strongly.

A bigger labor force means this expansion has even more scope to continue, bringing more people along!

There's a bit of a goldilocks feel to this latest report.

It's not too cold, and with payrolls growth averaging +378k per month(!), it puts an end to any talk the U.S. economy is in recession.

It's not too hot, with a sharp rise in participation, and more sustainable job growth

Nonfarm payrolls adding +315k in August, and the unemployment rose a tick to 3.7%. July's jobs growth was revised down by -2k, and June was revised down by -105k.

All told, this is a very healthy labor market, which is now improving at a slower rate (as the Fed and others hoped)

Perhaps we economists should stop always being dismal. It's a day to celebrate folks being able to find work, despite an incredibly challenging pandemic and difficult global conditions. If you're not in the job you love, look around, because this is a moment full of opportunity.

We economists are meant to be a grim bunch, so lemme add the pessimism. This jobs report is definitely closer to "too hot" than Goldilocks might like. The biggest threat to the U.S. economy right now is the possibility of inflation becoming entrenched, rather than recession.

Or let's pretend we work in Washington, and play "pick a number." The annualized rate of nominal wage growth over the past:
1 month: 5.8%
2 months: 5.6%
3 months: 5.2%
6 months: 4.5%
12 months: 5.2%

Let's take that 5.2% annual wage growth, and see where it comes from. Over the past six months, nominal earnings have growtn at an annualized rate of 4.5%, which isn't that worrying. Importantly, it's much lower than 5.9% over the prior six months.

What's the underlying pace of wage growth and where's it going?
.Over the past 3 months, hourly earnings have grown at an annualized rate of +5.2%, up from 3.9% over the prior 3 months. Sounds like it's rising.
.But wage growth was +5.9% in the prior 3 months & +5.9% before that

Nominal wage growth heated up a bit: It rose by 0.5% in July, and is up 5.2% over the year. That's getting a bit more uncomfortable in terms of possible impacts on inflation, though given that wages haven't kept up with prices, one imagines sellers can absorb some of this.

The enormously more important question is what's happening to core inflation. That looks to have some momentum in it, and the indirect effects of lower energy prices may take a while to pass through. So my forecast of precisely when that peaks is: ¯\_(ツ)_/¯ https://t.co/nSRvUG2qAt

Okay, what's the bigger picture? With gas prices having declined over the past few weeks, it's likely that we've seen the peak in the monthly headline inflation numbers.
Enough of the optimism. The real cause for pessimism is that rents are rising, and they'll continue to contribute to inflation for quite a while: https://t.co/q75w9Q56sQ

Striking to see that cars continue to be part of the inflation story. New vehicle prices rose another 0.7%, and used cars rose 1.6%. Together, they account for nearly 0.1 of the 0.7% rise in the core CPI. That's another sector where one hopes (expects?) supply chains to unfurl.

The effect of energy prices on headline CPI is just striking. In June, energy prices contributed literally half of the total rise in the CPI! [Contribution of 0.638 points of the 1.3% monthly rise] Over the year, energy prices (directly) contributed one third of the 9.1% rise.

The good news -- if you can call it that -- is that there's not really much evidence of things getting worse in the service sector (ex energy). The last few monthly numbers are +0.6, +0.7, +0.6, +0.7. No question that's higher than we want, but at least it's not sharply worsening

To add some context, latest inflation numbers:
Canada: 7.7%
Euro zone: 8.6%
United States: 9.1% (today's number)
United Kingdom: 9.1%

A lot of our inflation problems (but not all) reflect energy/Russia/Ukraine.  Energy prices are up 41.6% over the year.

The good news: This was the June report and we know that gas prices have fallen since. Not only will gas not contribute to inflation next month, it'll subtract

Headline CPI rose by 1.3% in June, which is a tad above market expectations. That puts inflation at 9.1% over the year.

Lotta this was gasoline / Ukraine / energy etc. Core CPI rose 0.7%, to be up 5.9% over the year.

Not a happy picture, but hopefully better days are ahead.

Truth is, few (if any) economists understand how pandemic-stricken economies really work. We've spent our lives studying economies populated by healthy people with smoothly functioning supply sides.

The really difficult thing to remember (from a policy perspective) is that the past really can't provide much guidance. This is still a pandemic-wracked economy trying to get back on its feet and back to normal. The usual rules of the road don't really apply.

The really important question about our current inflationary moment is its persistence. Will it last? Will it gain its own momentum? 

No monthly number tells us much about this, but each passing month of data adds another reason to worry.

Ben's graph (below) points to the optimistic reading: Core inflation, while high, may actually be trending down. When thinking about the future, that's the more relevant index. We just wish it were more obviously trending down, and doing so faster.
https://t.co/xJh2Zl2z7X

Comparisons of the current inflationary moment to the Great Inflation are inapt. The "Great Inflation" ran from 1965 to 1982 and was spurred along by policy. The "covid spike" has so far run from 2021 to mid 2022, is driven by a pandemic, and the Fed has signaled it'll fight.

I think Adam summarizes the underlying dynamics -- and why they might change -- as well as anyone.
https://t.co/2CKxRBJ0k2

There's little evidence (yet) that a 1970s style wage-price spiral is underway. There's reason to be optimistic that many goods prices will actually fall. And while energy prices have risen, once they stop rising, they'll stop contributing to inflation.

An ounce of perspective. This report tell us about May. Future inflationary pressure depends on things like wage pressure (which has cooled somewhat), productivity growth (where I can be optimistic), and re-normalization of supply side (where recent news is good, but fragile).

But what's more worrying is persistent inflationary pressure. This report tells a pessimistic story of a broader rise in prices, and the shift in price pressures from goods (which reflects many pandemic-related pressures) to services (where inflation was yet to really emerge).

A lot of the pain that people feel reflects forces that are real, but unlikely to persist. So headline inflation is partly driven by a 10.1% rise in food prices (11.9% for "food at home" which is prices at the grocery store), and a whopping 34.6% rise in energy (mostly gas)

We knew that goods prices were rising quickly, but now Services (less energy) are up 5.2% over the past year. The past six readings 0.2, 0.4, 0.5, 0.6, 0.7 and 0.6 sort of point in an unhappy direction.

Honestly, if you're not feeling happier after this jobs report, you're a professional grump.
The labor market is closer to too hot than too cold. That's a much better problem to have. Indeed, I've spent much of the past twenty years hoping to (finally!) see a labor market that's too hot.

Of course inflation is troublingly high. The question is how persistent it'll be. External shocks (Russia, covid, supply chains etc) aren't likely to fuel ongoing price rises. Persistent inflation comes from persistent wage pressure, where the news is concerning but not worrying.

Look, I know that folks are somehow averse to good news on the economy, but we've learned:
- Unemployment is low and most folks who want a job can find one
- Employment continues to grow at astounding rates
- Signs of persistent inflationary pressure are weaker than feared

The industry composition of job growth is what you would expect of an economy trying to get back to a new post-pandemic normal. Leisure and hospitality are hiring, folks are getting back to the office, and the remote parts of the economy remain strong. Services lead the charge. https://t.co/MoJrl2n0zT

The flipside of all of this is that workers real wages (ie adjusted for inflation) continue to fall, as they've done throughout most of the recovery.

For all the talk of workers gaining bargaining power, they're actually falling behind.
Point is, lotta people are looking for evidence of an emerging wage-price spiral. Yet we're really just not seeing it (yet). And every day it doesn't emerge is a day we can breathe a little easier.

Wage growth is critically important to the inflation outlook. This month's growth of only 0.3% in hourly earnings will be something of a relief to the Fed.

Wage growth for the past 3 months has been 3.7% (annualized), compared to 5.9% over the preceding 3 months.
Household survey is a bit weaker (and a lot less accurate), and it shows employment falling by -353k. Unemployment also fell by -11k. First time in a while that participation didn't keep shooting up.

We've added +523k jobs per month on average, over the past 3 months. In normal times, we'd call that a boom. (It's not entirely normal; the economy is still re-normalizing.)

It's hard to see where all that recession talk is coming from. This is a recovery with a lotta momentum.

Payrolls grew a very healthy +428k in April, and the unemployment remains unchanged at a very low 3.6%.

Relatively small revisions subtracted -39k over the previous two months.

This is a labor market that's just motoring along.

@AgeDiscrimUS The Fed cares. The inflation target is a PCE target.

Summary:
- Inflation is high
- Much of this is due to temporary factors, so headline inflation is likely to fall in coming months
- Core inflation is not only lower, but lower than many anticipated (good news!)
- Looking forward, the big concern is slowly rising service inflation

Inflation is a very important concern right now, but breathless headlines overstate the point.

Most private-sector forecasts see inflation as peaking this month or maybe next (if more bad things don't happen), so hold on... things may be about to get better.

The reason for focusing on "core" measures of inflation is not to deny the (very real!) fact that the cost of living is rising, but to get a sense of how much inflationary momentum there is.

Core inflation is quite a bit lower than headline.
Also, PCE inflation is lower than CPI
This is a good point: Rising food and gas prices probably hurt the poor more, because they're a bigger share of their budgets. https://t.co/yQP4VMX7Vu

But services account for 60% of our spending, and inflation remains far lower there, at 5.1% (or 4.7% less energy)

Of greater concern, service price inflation is slowly and gradually ramping up. This month was the highest in a while.

Goods price inflation is still leading the charge with goods prices rising +14.2% over the year. That a story of a surge in demand meeting unlucky supply disruptions: The pandemic, chip shortages, China's factories opening and closing, Russia hurting energy prices, shipping etc

There are a bunch of good whose prices are temporarily elevated, and if those prices unwind, they'll actually fall, pulling the inflation rate down with them. For instance, used car prices fell -3.8% last month, but they have a lot further to fall.

One key problem right now is that the most salient prices are rising at rapid rates. Prices for food at home (the grocery store, basically) rose 10% over the year. Gas rose 48%.

While these prices are salient, they collectively only account for 12% of spending.

Headline CPI rose +1.2% in March, for a year-ended rate of 8.5%.

Core inflation slightly lower than anticipated, rising by only 0.3%, yielding a year-ended rate of 6.5%.

Obviously inflation is higher than we hope. But this report is slightly better than anticipated.

Happy CPI day to all who celebrate (or in this case, commiserate).

Market expectations:
- Headline CPI inflation of 1.2% this month, dragging the annual up to 8.4%.
- Core inflation of 0.5% this month, for a year-ended rate of 6.6%

No, this is not recessionary. At all. https://t.co/3FerxFhbIi

And a reminder: We're only ever one variant away from an economic slowdown.

Two implications:
1. It's critical to invest in covid preparedness
2. There's a big and worrying downside attached to any economic forecast

The real question going forward is all about labor supply. We still have fewer jobs than before the pandemic. But the Omicron surge is behind us, and it's getting safer to return to work every day, and the question is how quickly will folks on the sidelines return.

It's pretty hard to make the case that now is the right moment for further stimulus of any kind. The economy has momentum and may be just a few months away from entering unchartered waters.

Unchartered doesn't mean dangerous; it just means we don't know how far we can go.

A funny thing is happening today: The rapid pace of jobs growth (and ongoing robust nominal wage growth) have raised my fears that inflation may be more persistent, but the failure to see any acceleration has moderated the fears of my more hawkish friends.
https://t.co/n5HS51rBxn

But with unemployment now at 3.6%, and the number of new jobs required to keep it stable as low as +50k, one really has to wonder how long this torrid pace of job growth can continue.

Ongoing gains are great, but unsustainably rapid gains less so.

The household survey shows employment grew by +736k and unemployment fell by -318k. So also strong numbers there.

There are 3 pieces of independent info the jobs report -- payrolls, revisions & household survey -- and they all registered  robust employment growth.

Hourly earnings rose +0.4% over the month, and last month's zero was revised to +0.1%. Over the year, private sector hourly earnings are up 5.6%.

Interesting to see one dissent: Bullard wanted to raise rates by half a percentage point instead of a quarter. Likely others agree on the need for such a rise, but disagreed on the appropriate timing.
The most notable addition to the Fed statement was the addition of Ukraine as a global risk "likely to create additional upward pressure on inflation and weigh on economic activity."

And no matter how you slice it, monetary policy remains remarkably geared for growth. The nominal rate is half a percentage point, and once you subtract your preferred measure of inflation, the real rate is robustly negative. The Fed has its foot nowhere near the brake.

It's not quite right to frame this as a contractionary shift in policy. What really matters for the economy is the real interest rate (the fed rate, less expected inflation). As inflation has risen, the Fed had to raise the nominal rate just to keep the real rate stable.

Realize that as supply chains become unfurled that it's not just that the good sector inflation will slow, but as prices -- say of used cars -- fall back to normal, they'll actually push inflation down. That's why many econs remain confident inflation will fall (in due course).

If you wanted to worry, the concern is that inflation is starting (slowly) to spread from the volatile (and supply chain affected) goods sector, to services.

Services inflation is 4.4% over the past year, and rose a tick to 0.5% in Feb. Keep your eye on the service sector.

When you focus on core CPI, you see that inflation is elevated, but there's no sense in which it's taking off. The last five monthly readings are 0.6% in October, 0.5% in November, 0.6% in December, 0.6% in January and 0.5% in February.

Of course, these are the numbers before the Russia-Ukraine conflict sent energy price up, so some more eye-catching headline inflation numbers are ahead of us. But keep your eye on core CPI to see what the real signal is.

CPI rose 0.8% last month, much as expected. Over the year, inflation was 7.9%. Big contributions from gas, shelter and food. 

Core CPI rose a calmer 0.5% (again as expected), and is up 6.4% over the year.

There will be lots of headlines, but this is the number everyone expected

Useful headline from @greg_ip that gets to the bottom line of this morning's jobs report: "No Stag, Less Flation."

I don't often write this, but: This was an unambiguously strong jobs report. Strong payrolls growth. Similar strength in the household survey. Broad-based gains. People getting back to work. Robust revisions. And signs that wage growth may not be the constraint some had feared.

One wonders whether it's time to revise concerns about an inflationary wage-price spiral. Yes, prices (and particularly headline) prices are rising. But over the past 1, 2, 3, or 4 months, growth in hourly earnings has risen at an annualized rate of less than 5%.

February's strong payrolls report is arguably not that surprising, given that Omicron-related hiring delays likely boosted this month's number. What's more surprising is how much job growth persisted through January's Omicron surge. Either way, the labor market is motoring along.
Household survey also shows pretty strong job growth, and is reporting employment is up +548k.
Some part of this restrained wage growth might be compositional, as +179k leisure and hospitality jobs returned, many of which may be lower wage. Still.

But here's the really big surprise: Despite huge payrolls growth and low unemployment, hourly earnings barely grew (they rose 1 cent!) in February. That means wages are up 5.1% over the past year, which is much less of an inflationary threat than prior trends had suggested.
Over the past three months, payrolls growth has averaged +582k jobs per month. At that rate, whatever labor market slack that remains will disappear pretty rapidly.

Very very strong payrolls report: +678k jobs in February, with unemployment edging down to 3.8%. Add in solid positive revisions that added a total of +92k to the past two months, and this is a job market that's really motoring.

Going forward, the good news is that as supply chains untangle, durable goods inflation may do more than halt -- these prices are likely to fall. The bad news is that implied rent is a huge share of the CPI, and ongoing rises in implied rent are pretty much locked in.

It remains striking just how unbalanced inflation is right now: Goods prices are up +12.3% over the year, while services are up +4.6%. Within the goods sector, durables are up +18.4% (supply chains, anyone?), and non-durables are up +9.8%.

CPI rose +0.6% in January, putting it up 7.5% over the year. Core CPI also up +0.6% in Jan, and so is now 6% over the year.

Not that far away from expectations, but also not good news, and sometimes the absence of good news is the real news.

Also, there are a lot of interesting and important gender and employment stories coming out of the pandemic. This thread simply notes that handwringing about one monthly change (in January's jobs report) is misplaced. No-one should ever makes sweeping claims based on one report.

In all of this, I don't blame any journalist for taking the published statistics at face value (when the qualifications are buried in the end notes). The method the BLS uses to make these population adjustments is opaque, and apt to create confusion, and I know it can do better.

So the entire differential rise in employment by gender in January is a statistical artefact. You can also see this in a separate survey (the firm survey), which did not make the same adjustment, and which shows no change in January in the share of jobs held by women. https://t.co/tb61P3cEDc

Nothing dramatic happened to female employment in Jan. Rather, the Census Bureau updated its population weights, which included more men than previously understood. Given survey estimates of the employment rate by gender, this mechanically raises the estimate of male employment. https://t.co/q6CbgaJMNl

Longer version: Our employment numbers come from surveys. Those surveys must be weighted to reflect the population. January's numbers use different weights than December's, so they can't be directly compared. Here's the BLS: https://t.co/25WdA0pUHw https://t.co/4UWrgzB6ZZ

Hourly earnings rose by 0.7% in January, and 5.7% over the year. If there had been big job losses, one might have blamed composition effects. That employment grew strongly both overall and in low-wage industries says that wage growth really is gaining momentum.

This is a good point: There were any number of "technical" and Omicron-related factors that might have led to a weak payrolls report, and that might have led you to dismiss that weakness. Harder to dismiss the evidence of strength in these payrolls numbers
https://t.co/AANkVPh4vK

But if you were looking for Omicron's effects, you might be surprised to see employment in leisure and hospitality grew +151k (of which +108k is due to restaurants and bars), and retail trade grew +61k (with little change in construction, manufacturing, info, finance etc)
You can see Omicron in these data though: The average work week fell by 0.2 hours, likely due to a lot of people being out.

This is a good point: There were any number of "technical" and Omicron-related factors that might have led to a weak payrolls report, and that might have led you to dismiss that weakness. Harder to dismiss the evidence of strength in these payrolls numbers
https://t.co/AANkVPh4vK

Still, it's surprising that in Omicron's peak month payrolls growth was stronger than employment growth in the household survey, given that Omicron might lead you to keep your job, but not be issued a paycheck (especially if you're paid weekly and don't have paid leave).

Even so, worth noting that the data showing the employment rate rose by 0.2 percentage points is unrepresentative, as 0.3 percentage points was due to a technical statistical issue. In reality, the employment rate fell by -0.1 percentage point.

While the new population controls have big effects on "levels" like the number of people employed, most of this is just due to estimating a larger population. As such, there are minimal effects on important ratios, like the unemployment rate or employment-to-population rate.

We usually put a lot more weight on the payrolls survey than the household survey. But if Omicron forced you to take a week off work (and if you don't have paid leave), then you're counted as one less job in the payrolls survey, but no change in the household survey.

The household survey appears to shows that employment rose +1,199k, which would be huge. But all of this (plus some) is due to a statistical adjustment (using new population weights). Comparing apples to apples, the household survey says employment fell -272k. https://t.co/TGxULd5Nzo
That'll help you understand January's strong payrolls numbers a bit: The economy hit Omicron with momentum. That was enough they could play it out to a draw.

Over the past three months, payrolls growth has averaged +392k per month, a *much* healthier rate of growth than anyone had understood.

Growth over the previous 3 months was also revised up a bit. So the 2nd half of 2021 was much better than we thought. The recovery had momentum

We have benchmark revisions to the payrolls survey, which now means the last three months showed growth of +467k (Jan), +510k (Dec) and +647k (Nov). Those are massive upward revisions (adding +398k in November, and +311k in December).

Super complicated jobs report coming, so don't take any headline number at face value. Everything needs qualification, thought, and an understanding of the technical and pandemic-related influences that distort the January jobs report.

@jbarro The price level is indeterminate in most macro models, which means the price of the unit of account (ie money) is also indeterminate. If Bitcoin becomes the unit of account, it inherits this property. That's not a crypto problem, that's a money problem.

@jbarro You make many good points, but a better analogy for what the right price of crypto should be is to ask either what the price of gold should be (obvious analogy), or to probe a bit more deeply, what the price of a dollar bill should be (in terms of goods).

Here's the huge caveat: The "reference period" for the household survey was Dec 5-11. The reference payroll period for the payrolls survey is the pay period including Dec 12. Omicron was barely a factor back then.

We're only learning about our pre-Omicron pre-history.

There's something pretty interesting going on in the household survey, which suggests that employment grew by 4.3m in the second half of 2021 (a rate of +727k per month). By contrast, payrolls says we added only 3m jobs (a rate of +508k).

FWIW the latter is usually more reliable
The household survey provides a more upbeat reading, suggesting that employment grew +651k, which is why the unemployment rate fell to a pretty good 3.9%.

So the economy didn't hit what I fear is a severe Omicron shock with any momentum. It dawdled into Omicron, and as you can see all around you, that has since caused all sorts of disruption that'll take months to unwind, even when the surge in cases is behind us.

Over the past three months payrolls employment has grown, on average, by +365k per month, which is okay, but not the sort of growth you might hope for.

And the past two months are consistent with a real slowdown in the recovery.

Remember, these are all pre-Omicron data.

@jmackin2 Yes, it's *possible* that stocks could rise a small amount every day, yielding high avg growth, lots of peaks, and low vol. But think how unlikely that path is. By contrast there are many paths with high average volatility, yielding high average growth and many peaks.

In a standard economic model the rise in stocks is a sufficient statistic for our improving economic prospects. The more often the market hits new peaks along the way likely reflects volatility of that path, and so is actually more a measure of economic trouble than of bliss.

Table 3 describes a range of micro concepts, and lists the intro textbooks that they judge as "best practice" in illustrating them. I tallied up the totals, and you can see the results, below.

(Yes, the biggest bar is Stevenson and Wolfers.) https://t.co/nXVOfoL3OL

The authors conclude that too often "students are left without enough exposure to the core concepts of microeconomics – including ones that underpin macroeconomic models."

I think that's right for an earlier generation of economists. But modern macros emphasize microfoundations.

So I was very interested to read a paper by Marianne Johnson, Alexander Kovzik & Nancy Burnett about the ways in which microeconomic concepts animate introductory econ courses.

The authors read 20 leading econ textbooks and analyzed the relevant content.
https://t.co/xSdyhWMgQN https://t.co/mRlZXNvPVH

Econ teaching 🧵

Macroeconomics has shifted over recent decades to emphasize microfoundations. This is a critical evolution, and I believe we should lead into it our undergrad classes.

It's good macro. And it's good pedagogy, helping students see the relevance to their lives.

A reasonable guess: There's been a lot of work done inside the Fed on short- and medium-term labor force projections, and these have been quite influential in internal debates.

The implication is that we're currently near what the Fed regards as full employment, but we can afford to run the economy a bit hotter -- so that employment growth to slightly outstrips  underlying population growth -- for quite a few years.

Basically the pandemic led to a wave of early retirements. Many of those early retirees aren't coming back. Over the next 5-10 years that cohort will approach the age when they would have otherwise retired, leading aggregate participation to drift back to its pre-pandemic trend.

Summarizing what Powell's saying about the labor market: Prime-age employment is near full employment. We're still missing jobs because the olds aren't coming back to work. A hot labor market (during covid) won't bring them back, so expect participation to recover only slowly.

While the Fed has officially retired the term 'transitory,' it's forecasts sure still look like it expects the current inflation surge to be transitory. This year's PCE inflation is expected to be 5.3%, falling to 2.6% in 2022, 2.3% in 2023, and 2.1% in 2024. https://t.co/Utekw797HP

There were a lot of people who underestimated Guido Imbens for a long time. The work he was doing was always great; he just got caught in the crosshairs of a sometimes acrimonious methodological war.
https://t.co/Mqh8DPRM8g
Unrelated true story: The last time I saw Guido Imbens was at Legoland.

This year's prize reaffirms a trend we've seen for years: If you want to win the Prize, you've got to win the next generation of graduate students. Teach them tools that they can use to push back the frontier. Each of these guys has trained a veritable army of graduate students.

The truly notable thing about today's Econ Nobel is that it's a prize for work that has been felt across so many fields. The credibility revolution they kicked off has transformed empirical work in political science, sociology, criminology, demography, public health, the law, etc

Orley Ashenfelter, who by some measures kicked off the credibility revolution, was surely a bit unlucky to not be included here. The Princeton IR section had a huge influence here: Orley started the revolution, and hired David and Alan, and trained Josh.

And today, it's hard not to notice that Alan Krueger is no longer with us. Alan would surely have shared this prize. He was so interesting, so exciting, and he made this economic revolution so much fun. He may have been the most creative of all of these guys. Rest in peace, Alan.

An aside: I don't think I've ever seen the Nobel committee describe particular fractions of a prize for each laureate. Maybe they think they can credibly estimate the contributions of each (dad joke).

No quibble with it; just an observation.

The right answer, of course, is that the best tools to use depend on the question you're asking, and David, Josh and Guido have added really important tools to the economic toolkit. We can do credible causal analysis now, and that need not crowd out theory, or general equlibrium.

Another version of this critique is that the focus on credibility has led some economists to look under the lamppost, focusing on the questions we have the "natural experiments" to answer well, rather than the questions that most need to be answered.

And that's why today's Nobel, while well deserved, will be a bit controversial. To some economists, the credibility revolution led economists to abandon economic theory (even as it has emphasized more careful statistical theorizing).

The credibility revolution has had less impact in macro, and that's because it's difficult to think of experiments that also account for the spillover effects from one person or one market to the other. Those "general equilibrium" effects are absolutely central to macro.

And those tools have revolutionized the work that applied microeconomists have done, on everything from crime to family to labor markets to development. It's been a revolution in our lifetimes, and it's been a privilege to have a ring-side seat.

So Josh said: Isn't getting a low Vietnam draft number a bit like that experiment -- of randomly being assigned to military service. And aren't folks with high draft numbers a bit like the treatment group.

So he developed tools to analyze the results of this "natural experiment"

Josh's paper on the draft is an example. One way to figure out the effects of military service on outcomes would be to run an experiment, randomly giving some people the "treatment" of serving.

But it's impossible and unethical to run that experiment...

And so the next generation of empirical economists focused on analyzing credible "natural experiments."

Economists often can't run true experiments. But nature has a way of running a sort-of experiment. And those can help you make causal claims.

Then David, Josh and Guido said: Hang on.

Their response wasn't the usual destructive "we can't make causal claims" stuff, but rather entirely constructive: Here's a toolkit and set of approaches to help you make credible causal claims.

Short version of the prize: We used to dig into the data, say "correlation ain't causation," quickly forget we said that, and make a bunch of causal-ish statements based on data that really couldn't support such claims.

While this analysis comes from the White House, it’s written by two of the leading tax scholars of their generation. It’s serious stuff. You might quibble with specific details, but it’s not going to change the big picture that the very rich face very low federal income tax rates

The analysis calculates average tax rates for the rich over the period 2010-18. This lower federal income tax rate is not a one-year anomaly, but a persistent result of the loopholes built into U.S. tax law.
Obvious implication: If past studies understated the income of the rich, they overstated the income tax *rates* the rich pay.

This new estimate does something quite important: It analyzes a measure of income that includes unrealized capital gains. The rich earn a lot of this income, but because it’s difficult to calculate, few estimates of tax rates include it. https://t.co/jCZV01k83H

Here’s why:
1. The rich rely on investment income, which is taxed at lower rates than labor income.
2. They pay no income tax on a big chunk of their investment income. (This is the “stepped up basis” loophole.) https://t.co/1pc8CEXlf2
Stunning new estimates suggest that the 400 wealthiest American families paid an average Federal tax rate of only 8.2%. https://t.co/vb9HtdKVRT

Anyway this thread started with a comment on the collective action problem that the vax mandate solves. The CEO of Columbia Sportswear provides an unbelievably clear articulation of the competing forces at play, and how the vax mandates solves them. https://t.co/bFRMcXT9Rn

Customers want safety from the virus. This provides an incentive for businesses to supply that safety. But this incentive only exists if biz can credibly signal that safety to customers. The certification gives them the incentive to provide the safety that customers desire.

My policy idea is for the government provide a certification — a sticker you can place in your shop window that says “we’re all vaxxed.” This will allow small businesses that choose to vaccinate their staff to compete with big businesses on this safety dimension.

The vax mandate only applies to large employers, and so may be a competitive advantage for large companies, because customers know they’ll be safe there. Small businesses who do have vaccinated staff need a way to signal that they’re just as safe.

Point is in many industries all of the major players want fully vaccinated staff, but none wants to bear the political heat of announcing this first. Result: None of them require it even if all of ‘em want to.

The mandate solves the problem of waiting for a first mover to emerge

The vax mandate solves a collective action problem:

Businesses want to vax their staff to provide a safe workplace. But they’re each worried that if they move first, they’ll lose staff to their rivals (who probably also want vaxxed staff). Mandating the vax solves this problem.

@ethanbdm Your comments suggest (correctly imo) that econ teaching has moved as the discipline has shifted. But the interesting thing about teaching Intro is that it is a foundational class, and so it really is the one class you teach where your students will challenge every assumption.

Over the past year I've talked to dozens and perhaps hundreds of Econ 101 instructors around the country, and I'm constantly inspired by the careful thought, passion, and insight this generation of instructors bring to the job. This is not your father's economics.

A problem with the Econ 101 Discourse is that it's often informed by a critic's hazy memories of one or two classes taken years ago.

Today's reality is that many instructors teach a vibrant, open-minded and interesting version of the class. Some fail but many succeed. #teachecon

Today's jobs data were collected in early July and reflect  decisions made in June.

Some part of the story is changing seasonal patterns in hiring by schools -- related to their reopening -- and local government education jobs contributed +221k to July's payrolls growth.

Unemployment fell a lot because more people got jobs. Participation actually rose a tick (though it has further to go).

Pretty helpful revisions add another +119k to May/June.
Volatility is a thing, so better to focus on the three month average of jobs gains running at +801k per month, which is pretty great, but also pretty necessary given the depth of the hole we're in.
BOOM! Payrolls growth of +943k in July, and unemployment down from 5.9% to 5.4%, and that's what a robust jobs report looks like.

Right now Delta is causing U.S. case numbers to double every week-and-a-bit.

So the 14-day case average is 50k.
The 7-day case average is 63k.
Monday was 87k.
Tuesday was 109k.

Suggests the current rate is pretty damn high (though weekend numbers will be much lower)

A lot of covid reporting focuses on 14-day averages, which smooths out noise and eliminates (big!) day-of-the-week effects.

The cost is that the average lags reality, which is a big deal during periods of rapid change (like right now!)

@Scott_E_Page OMG, you wrote a paper on it!!! (Just read it; it's a nice piece, and the failure to improve much with ten doors is quite surprising.)
Point is, the door you picked was a random guess, while Monty is giving you a curated selection. (And conditional probability is all about thinking careful about curated selections...)

I've not seen this intuitive reframing of the Monty Hall problem before, but it makes the problem so clear: What if there are 100 doors and Monty eliminates 98 of them, leaving the one you chose, and the one Monty left. Now it's pretty clear which is a better bet to have the goat

The simpler (political economy) interpretation is that Toomey is a politician representing vested interests, and so he's worried that if policy that accounts for the specific experiences of various minority groups, then it will no longer advantage the majority that he represents.

The only way I can make sense of Toomey's tirade (beyond the obvious—politics, duh), is that he's pushing for a return to representative agent models.

Much of modern macro is about getting rid of representative agent assumptions, in favor of a richer microeconomic understanding.

Failing to understand the causes of racial and other disparities means failing to understand the choices many make and the constraints they face. Failing to gain insight into any subset of economic agents will only weaken our understanding of the macroeconomy.

Look, here's the problem: Macroeconomic outcomes reflect the microeconomic decisions made by millions of people. It's impossible to understand the macroeconomy without understanding the choices and constraints people face, and these often vary by race/ethnicity/class/gender etc

If counterfactual you would have interpreted a strong payrolls report as evidence that labor demand was running ahead of labor supply stoking concern about a ‘labor shortage,’ then you shouldn’t also be in the business of seeing a weak payrolls report and yelling ‘labor shortage’
This one simple trick can turbo charge the recovery: Get vaxxed, get your friends to join you, make the marketplace safe, and watch people return.

Utterly baffling to see a recovery stalling with 8 million fewer jobs and then hear talk of a ‘labor shortage.’

Do you really think 8 million people lost the will to work?

Sound like weak labor demand.

Or if it’s labor supply, it’s not a labor shortage, it’s a safety shortage.

We are still 8 million jobs below pre-pandemic levels, or about 10 million jobs below where we would have been if pre-covid trends had continued. That’s why we need much faster job growth. 

There are millions in need, an economy that remains sick, and a recovery that’s ailing.

The other sorta disappointing part of this report comes from revisions to the prior two months, which we had thought looked kinda great. February job growth was revised up by 68,000, but March was revised down by 146,000, so recent history is -78k worse than we had thought.
Unemployment is stuck at 6.1%, well above the pre-pandemic rate of 3.5%, and that’s despite the fact that millions are still not looking for work.

U.S. payrolls grew by +266k, which would be fabulous in normal times, but is utterly disappointing at a moment in which forecasters expected +1 million jobs, and we’re still missing millions of pre-pandemic jobs.

This is a big miss that changes how we think about the recovery.

If the Phillips Curve is much flatter — and over recent decades it appears to be really quite flat — then the forecast moderate overheating will lead to an even smaller inflation response.

Beyond 2021, it appears that the Fed isn't risking much of  an inflation overshoot at all!

These forecast changes imply the Fed's working off a pretty steep Phillips Curve
2021 E[U] ↓0.5 => E[π] ↑0.4
2022 E[U] ↓0.3 => E[π] ↑0.1
2023 E[U] ↓0.2 => E[π] ↑0.1

In sum, a shock lowering unemployment by 1.0%-pt-years is expected to reduce inflation by 0.6%-pt-years.

Economist @nancymbirdsall thinks that maybe economics has gotten more hostile to women over time, as they’ve now gained enough of a foothold in the profession to be seen as serious competition. (We don’t have comparable data over time, so can’t say.)

Are things improving? Economist @Dstrassman started a similar project in the 1980s, but when her colleagues got wind of it, they removed her from the seminar distribution list.
https://t.co/aYaLdVgRy1

The most depressing statistic is implicit in our paper: 97 young econs collaborated with us on this research, yet only 57 were willing to be individually named as coauthors. Many feared retaliation from advisers or future employers.
 
To me, this qualifies as making good trouble

Our research was the result of a massive effort in which young economists decided to gather data on something that mattered to them: Economics seminar culture.
 
We now have facts to complement anecdotes and intuition.
 
Our collaborators are *amazing*, and deserve all credit. https://t.co/9CG51UkXFp

Lemme share a shitty take. Some folks have noted that our data was largely collected by women, as if that undermined the findings. Visit the BLS or Census, and you’ll discover that nearly all econ data is largely collected by women. (Somehow that never seemed relevant before.)

We wish we could compile similar evidence of differential treatment of economists by race or ethnicity. But economics is so overwhelmingly white that there are so few people of color in economics that it would have been impossible to draw statistically significant conclusions. https://t.co/OdMFv7wSSt

It's time we say this part out loud: Our findings speak to “an undercurrent of misogyny” in economics.
 
Our research adds to a literature on gender biases in econ in which "every rock we look under reveals yet another way in which existing institutions are biased against women." https://t.co/9UAfJRvm79

Economists who fear losing the rigor inherent in our current combative seminars must realize that it comes at a very real cost.
 
I'm struck by how many econs seem to believe that obnoxious behavior is a complement to rigor; surely it’s a substitute. https://t.co/lSzG5hkDcT

Our results cohere with findings from a survey of American Economic Association members, which found that 48%(!!!)  of women had refrained from presenting an idea at work to avoid disrespect.
 
This is a huge loss, as so many smart insights are simply never voiced in our seminars https://t.co/qNmUhozleH

Our analysis focuses on how women are *treated* differently than men in econ seminars. But that’s not the whole story. Economics has a famously aggressive seminar culture, and that hostility — even if equally applied — may take a greater toll on women and other outgroups. https://t.co/mCo2x1cGEx

Many women economists have told me that this research describes — statistically and with lots of tables and charts — their lived experiences. Hearing their personal stories brings these numbers to life, suggesting that economics really must do better.
https://t.co/Or5ayAu3Rx

Economists often prefer objective data, so we focus on how many questions were asked. But being asked more questions may not be all bad — it may show interest! So we also recorded subjective assessments of the questions, finding that women were more likely to be treated unfairly https://t.co/N2BHuO9XeY

These findings matter. Our sample includes 176 “job market talks,” which are seminars where recent doctoral students present as part of the interview process for faculty positions.
 
These talks can make or break your career.
 
Gender differences were even starker in job talks. https://t.co/K9H7mzEpaT

Our paper represents from a massive data collection effort, in which our team coded up *every interaction* between a speaker and their audience in 176 job talks, 286 regular econ seminars, and 443 presentations at a top econ conference https://t.co/Q6XsMaw5gg

THREAD: My coauthors and I have a new NBER working paper out studying economics seminars.
 
Our findings: Women receive around 12% more questions when presenting, including more hostile and patronizing questions.

A technical side note. A recession is defined as a period of declining economic activity. By this logic the initial covid recession which started in February ended a few months later when the rebound started.

Today's numbers may signal that a second recession began in late 2020.

Part of our economic crisis stems from our political crisis. Charlatans like @StephenMoore argued the problem was restrictions on business rather than a deadly virus.

Public health measures were relaxed, the virus spread, the economy stalled.
https://t.co/8E6GcPAPLP

The economic diagnosis here is simple: There's no economic health without public health. The surest way to restart the economy is to beat the bug.

To those who doubted this, we've tried your experiment, and it led to a third wave of covid, and an economic reversal.

But there's a big unforced error that'll extend this economic crisis: The failure to provide aid to state and local governments means that they're cutting back, firing teachers and the like. It's totally unnecessary, but obviously follows from the logic of balanced budget rules. https://t.co/XbYPg922zd

There's obviously no doubt that the third wave of covid is the cause of our current economic ills, and as a result, we lost nearly half a million jobs in leisure and hospitality. https://t.co/Ow252DxzYq

And this is an economic crisis that's disproportionately hurting the poor.

You can see this is a rather extraordinary statistic: Average wages are rising, but that's because low-wage workers are losing their jobs, leaving only high-wage workers in the average. https://t.co/s1gEixBkHR

The household survey doesn't really have any better news. It shows employment growth of a meager +21k, and so unemployment is only as low as it is (a still elevated 6.7%) because of an extraordinary exodus from the labor force.
Millions are jobless, thousands are dying, and it's because dozens in DC are dithering.
We're in the midst of a political crisis, during a public health crisis, and an economic crisis.

But there's no way around the depressing fact that the economy is in a hole as deep or deeper than anything following the financial crisis, the mechanical bounceback is behind us, and further progress has stalled.
The glimmer of good news here (and it's only a glimmer) is that October and November were stronger than we thought, and revisions added +135k to those months.

In December the U.S. economy lost -140,000 jobs, and THE RECOVERY HAS STALLED JUST LIKE I WARNED.

We lost 22 million jobs in Feb & March, then regained half of them, and now we've stalled, with the economy in a deeper jobs hole than the darkest days after the financial crisis.

@SethAckerman @BetseyStevenson @jasonfurman @snaidunl @paulkrugman Seth, not quite. When buyers have market power, their demand decisions depend on the sellers' responses, and when sellers have market power, their supply decisions depend on buyers' responses. There are no longer unique supply & demand curves, as each depends on the other.

@SethAckerman @BetseyStevenson @jasonfurman @snaidunl @paulkrugman In writing down a market demand curve, you've just abstracted from any monopsony power. The P-Q relationship is only 1:1 under price-taking behavior.

The recovery was always going to be a play in two acts.

The first act was firms re-opening and recalling furloughed workers.

The second act is harder: Millions lost their jobs permanently & there aren't many new opportunities opening up for them.

The second act is a grim slog.

You can't interpret economic numbers separately from the broader public health context. The pandemic changes what one might mean by "good jobs" and "bad jobs."
https://t.co/4RHutW5Q4E
Over half of this month's job growth is in the stay-at-home-because-of-the-virus sector. https://t.co/zRkqo8Njr6

We're already seeing the recessionary impulse from state and local governments cutting back.
- State governments cut -243k jobs in March-May, and now an additional 134k since September.
- Local governments cut -1255k jobs March-May, and -187k since Sept.

And more cuts are ahead.

And if you think an unemployment rate of 6.7% doesn't sound too bad, realize that this largely reflects millions of people dropping out of the labor force -- millions more than in a typical downturn -- because it's barely safe to leave their houses. https://t.co/ZbqOwhYhwm

The household survey suggests that employment actually declined (by -74k) last month. So the fall in unemployment from 6.9% to 6.7% largely reflect the fact that an additional 400k people dropped out of the labor force.

The proximate causes of our slowing economy are obvious:
The virus is back, which hobbles the service sector, and stimulus has basically petered out, leaving the economy with little help. It doesn't have to be this way.

The dramatic ups and downs of recent months might hide the real story here: The economy is in a deep hole -- as deep as in the darkest days following the financial crisis -- and the recovery is faltering. Barely there. Making no progress. Stalled. Stopped.

Remember, the economy lost 22 million jobs, then gained roughly half of them back.

We still have 10 million fewer jobs than we did in February. Clawing the rest back at +245k per month will take basically forever. If this is the second half of the recovery, it's going to be grim

Payrolls in November rose a mere +245k. That's the sort of number you might see in a "normal" month, and definitely not what you're hoping for in the snapback from a covid-induced shutdown.

THE RECOVERY IS STALLING.

The flip side of the post-Thanksgiving surge in infections and deaths is that we can infer that those who stay home, wear masks and limit their interactions SAVE LIVES.

It'll never be easier for modest sacrifices to have huge effects.

Here's how much it matters:
Measuring output based on spending data says the economy is -3.6% below its potential.

Measuring output based on income data says that the economy is -4.9% below its potential.

(Or compared with their peaks, GDP is down -3.5%, GDI is down -4.7%) https://t.co/psdVtlFRLc

It's a reminder that covid has made all economic measurement much more difficult, and so we're very much flying blind. While historically GDI has been more accurate, that may not be so relevant, as it's hard to know whether covid has caused greater distortions to GDP or GDI.

This is the biggest difference I've ever seen between GDI and GDP growth. Remember, they're meant to measure the same thing, but each relies on different data sources. It's enormously consequential which is sending a truer signal.

BEA has published an update to its Q3 output numbers:

The spending-based measure (real GDP) grew 7.4% (this is the 33.1% annualized number that got all the headlines a few weeks back).

The (more reliable) income-based measure (real GDI) grew 5.8%, an annualized rate of 25.5%. https://t.co/HJsrilFlHu

So, my suggestion...

Talk to your fam, and ask them whether they would prefer to get together next week, or have a really joyous celebration in a few months which also includes the grandparents.

Lest you think it strange to move a holiday to accommodate an economic argument, it wouldn't be a first.

During the Great Depression, Roosevelt shifted Thanksgiving in an attempt to goose spending. Surely preventing the spread of a deadly virus is at least as worthwhile.

So my proposal is that the President announce that Thanksgiving will be on May 27.

It's not about legal enforcement, but rather pushing families to ask: Should we celebrate in November, or in May?

Turkey Day in May will be safer, more joyful, and can include more of the fam.

Thanksgiving gatherings in November are the opposite of "flattening the curve." Think about it: Millions of families taking infection risks *at the same time*.

This could easily overwhelm the hospitals, transforming severe cases into fatal ones.

But really, my proposal is about the public interest and protecting others. Your Thanksgiving gathering risks spreading the disease from high-risk areas to lower-risk areas. It's not just your family you may infect, but they may infect their broader community.

A vaccine over the horizon fundamentally changes the cost-benefit calculus. Avoiding the virus no longer just defers your bout with the bug. An infection deferred is now an infection prevented. A death deferred is a death avoided.

Precautions are now more valuable, not less.

Thanksgiving in May will be much less risky. The numbers are staggering. With case numbers soaring, there's roughly a forty percent chance that any indoor gathering of ten people has at least one covid case. It's higher in many parts of the country.
https://t.co/xwkoTBp1Ku

Here's the argument: Would you prefer a small Thanksgiving with masks and six-foot markers, or waiting a few months so you can invite your whole family, hug, shout, and yell at the TV?

Thanksgiving in May offer more opportunities for love and gratitude.

My latest @nytimes column puts forward a simple proposal: If we postpone Thanksgiving for six months — until after the elderly and the vulnerable have access to a vaccine — it will likely save hundreds of lives.

It's a simple, cheap, effective fix. https://t.co/JzhPE9XO9z

The most exciting (and somewhat speculative) finding is instructors who had prior experience with online instruction did nearly as well during the pandemic.

Two striking effects here:

So here's my advice: Surround yourself with people who haven't been primed to think about any specific mouse. Ask them if you're not seeing the ducks. And even if you can't see the ducks, admit they may be there.

Now, where can I find someone who's never heard of Mickey Mouse?

Think about our current political moment. It seems like a lotta two-legged ducks are being ignored. My first instinct is to say it's the other side that can't see the truth about ducks. But what if it's me? If a simple story about Mickey Mouse makes me so foolish, it could be me.

And I wondered: Is this what political speech is all about? Seduce me with stories of mice that close my mind so much that I forget about the reality there are two-legged ducks all around me (and not just in Anaheim).

Could a skillful politician pull this trick on me every day?

There's something clever about the set-up, that by priming me to think of Mickey Mouse, it narrowed my mind. Like an idiot, I thought that thinking of Donald as a two-legged duck made me clever. But really I was walking right into their trap. My mind was closed to all other ducks

A student told me the following joke…

Q: Can you name a mouse that walks on two legs?
Me: Mickey Mouse!
Q: And can you name a duck that walks on two legs?
Me: Donald Duck!
Them: All ducks walk on two legs, prof!!!

This joke works on others. Try it.

And that got me thinking...

Big picture. 
1. Perhaps our political crisis is receding. 
2. But the covid crisis is accelerating with record case numbers (still growing exponentially), high and rising covid deaths. 
3. The economic crisis is ongoing (and could worsen as the covid crisis worsens).
...and we're still waiting on payrolls reports from crucial Waukesha County.

The dynamics of shutting down and reopening are violent, and their whipsaw overwhelms everything else in the data. But once that's over (it's nearly over), the question is what sort of labor market will we be left with.

Right now, it looks like it's still in a significant slump.

Here's what's worrying me. The easy work of this recovery -- the mechanical snap back from recalling furloughed workers -- is largely done. That disguises a problem of rising unemployment due to folks who have permanently lost their jobs.
https://t.co/iNlZrKVb8n

Characterizing the economy:
1. It's in a deep hole
2. It used to be in a much deeper hole
3. So it's improving
4. But it's improving at a slow rate
5. And that slow rate isn't picking up
6. At least that slow rate of improvement isn't slowing
7. But rising covid could change that

Usually payrolls growth of +638k would be fantastic news. But right now, much less so.

The economy lost 22 million jobs Feb-Apr, and had made half of that back by Sept.

If we crawl back the remaining 11 million jobs at this rate, it'll take ages. The recovery is worryingly slow

Finally, while much of this thread can explain some of the divergence between markets and models, much remains unexplained. Frankly, I'm a bit puzzled.

And while this thread gives you reasons to doubt that markets will perform well this time, who knows, they could!

Having said all this, it's clear that prediction markets rate  Trump as more likely to win than most of the models do.

But if you want a markets-versus-models debate, this isn't a cycle with a well-functioning U.S. market, so it's not one where the markets are likely to shine.

I do think @Betfair will be useful for tracking the fluctuating fortunes of the candidates during the vote count. This is basically a math problem, and Europeans can do math as well as Americans! Think of it as operating a bit like a crowd-sourced "Needle."

Equally, Americans can't trade in the @BetFair market, which strikes me as problematic. Prediction markets work best when people are aggregating local knowledge. I'm not sure that's what European traders are doing.
https://t.co/tpVB7wgS8d

I'm more sympathetic to @BetFair, which rates Trump a 31% chance to win. That's still surprisingly pro-Trump, and there have been hundreds of millions bet in that market, and the distortions are much smaller. https://t.co/J2QpjVs2Pz

At the end of the day, savvy bettors aren't going to bother with all this hassle for $60 in expected profit.

So a major mis-pricing can easily persist. And that'a big part of my story for why the @PredictIt odds just don't look credible to me, and why that can be an equilibrium.

Now add hassle and trading limits. At PredictIt, I can only buy $850 worth of shares (which is 1416 Not Trump shares at $0.60 each).
If I thought Trump was actually a 20% chance, my expected return is 1416 shares x (20% x lose $0.60 per share + 80% x win $0.2028 per share) = $60.

Do the math, and realize that a bet that I could lose $600 on, and gain $202.8 on, is only worth it if I believe Trump to be less than a 25% chance to win (assuming risk neutrality). So a market price of 40 is consistent with a 25% chance of Trump winning.

All told, I stand to lose $600, and if I win, I'll get $912 back, for a gain of $312. But these winnings are taxable, and @predictit will issue a 1099 to any US resident who wins more than $600/year. If my marginal tax rate is 35%, then I only get to keep $202.8 of my winnings.

If Trump loses the election, I win my bet, but I have to pay 10% on my $400 in winnings, so now I'm down to $360. Then I have to pay 5% on all withdrawals, so if I want to withdraw the initial $600 I put in, plus the $360 I won, then that's another $48 in fees.

Let's say that I'm willing sell 1000 of these shares, effectively buying "Not Trump" shares for 60 cents. If so, I'll lose $600 if Trump wins. You might think that I stand to win $400 if Trump loses, but that's not quite the whole story, because  transaction costs are a big deal.

Right now, you can sell a share that pays $1 if Trump wins, for 40 cents. I would love to do that. But there are large transaction costs that get in the way, and they're so big that it would be wrong to infer that markets believe that Trump is anywhere near a 40% chance to win. https://t.co/NKdu347XE8

Lemme tell you a little about why I'm not putting much weight on prediction markets this election. The short version is that the main US market, @PredictIt, is structured in a way that allows big mis-pricings to persist.

And as I like to remind my students: Externalities aren't a side topic or an occasional market failure. They're everywhere, and nearly everything we do affects others in big ways and small, and we want to find a way to make these interactions better.

The topic of externalities is not just about vaccines, or masks, or global warming, but how your choices affect others, and how their choices affect you. Most importantly, it gives us the policy tools to ensure that we all take better account of the impacts we have on each other.

In the middle of a pandemic, there's no more vital economic concept to understand than externalities. And that's the topic we dive into in this week's episode of Think Like An Economist as we explore masks & vaccines in our econ-mini-course-meets-a-podcast https://t.co/PWrvscCkfT

I think what most of us care about is whether the economy has continued to recover after the mechanical bounceback in Q3.

To judge that, you'll need to look at more recent and high-frequency numbers, like those here: https://t.co/4HdDYF6IYH

If you want an up-to-date assessment of the state of the economy, economists rarely look to GDP. That's because the numbers are released with a long lag -- the mid-point of Q3 was back in mid-August -- and quarterly averages aren't much help in detecting month-to-month movements.

Lemme clarify what I mean here: Today's GDP numbers tell us about the average of July, August and September, relative to the average of April, May and June.

But we already had data through to October on tons of other informative indicators.

Watch the market (non-)response to today's GDP numbers, and you'll see what I mean. For all the political chatter, markets haven't responded at all. That's because there's not really much relevant news about the state of the economy in these numbers.

How informative are today's GDP data?

Not very. The growth from Q3 to Q2 reflects the depth of the Q2 hole as much as it reflects the size of the Q3 recovery. 

We already knew Q2 was horrible, and we all know Q3 was better. Tons of indicators have told us this.

Was this an unexpectedly large rebound?

Not really. Go back to the start of the year, and look at the forecasts from then, and most forecasters were expecting the economy to basically stop in Q2, and then largely rebound in Q3.

So where are we?

The economy is -3.5% smaller than it was in late 2019. Is that a big hole? Well, that's roughly as large as the hole the economy fell into during the financial crisis, and at the time we thought that a damn big hole.

There will be lots of political chatter about today's GDP number. It's true, Q3 is a record rate of growth. But note Q2 was a record contraction, the likes of which we've never seen before.

Big jump down, big bounce back. What really matters is that we're not all the way back.

Reporting *quarterly* GDP growth at an *annualized* rate answers the question: If the economy also grew at this rate for the next 3 quarters, how much larger would the economy be?

But there's no chance that will happen, so the annualized rate answers a question no-one is asking.

When the economy rises by +7.4%, some will report this as being at an "annualized rate" of 33.1%.

Lemme be crystal clear: This does not mean that the economy is now one-third bigger. (Lemme explain...)

GDP rose by +7.4% in Q3 (pretty much exactly as expected), after falling by -9.0% in Q2 and -1.3% in Q1. All told, the economy is -3.5% smaller than it was at the end of 2019.

For context, the economy is roughly as far below its peak as  in the darkest days of the last recession
